FacilityStr1: 2 miles east of Ray, ND, on Hwy 2

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This is an executive summary of the policies, procedures and activities for compliance with the EPA?s Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs under section 112 (r) of the Clean Air Act Amendments, 40 CFR 68.79, for Whiting Oil and Gas Corporation?s Ray Gas Plant.
Location and Status
The Ray Gas Plant is located in Williams County, approximately two (2) miles east of Ray, North Dakota.  The plant processes natural gas delivered from wells.  The plant processes consists of gas sweetening and separation of natural gas liquids (NGL).  The NGL product is stored in two NGL storage tanks.  The product is sold and shipped via truck.
Program Level
It has been determined that this is a Program 1 facility.  There are no public or environmental receptors within the range of the worst case release scenario.  This facility is subject to OSHA?s Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals regulation, 29 CFR 1910.119.  
Prevention and Response Policies
The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies are provided in the facility?s Process Safety Management Guidelines manual.  The plant's emergency response plan has been coordinated with the Williams County Local Emergency Planning Committee(LEPC) and agency personnel have toured the facility.  Whiting Oil and Gas Corp.  takes an active role in preventing accidental releases at its facility by ensuring that employees are trained in the safe operation of the plant and evacuation procedures.  
Stationary Source and Regulated Substances 
The facility contains a simple NGL product storage and shipping process.  Butane, propane and pentane are the primary components of the NGL inventory.  Propane is used as refrigerant in the refrigeration process.
Release Scenario
The worst case release scenario is that the single largest container is released over a ten (10) minute period, resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  No active mitigation is considered.  Worst case meteorological condit

ions are assumed and RMP*Comp was used to calculate the endpoint distance for overpressure of 1.0 pound per square inch (PSI) for a flammable mixture vapor cloud explosion.   A distance of 0.3 miles to the flammable endpoint was determined for a release of 80,209 pounds in ten minutes for the NGL process.  A distance of 0.3 miles to the flammable endpoint was determined for a release of 44,500 pounds in ten minutes for the propane refrigeration process.  
There are no public receptors within this distance. There are no environmental receptors within this distance.

Accident History
This is a new facility and therefore, has not experienced an incident that resulted in injuries or environmental damage as defined in the RMP rule in the past five years.
Emergency Response Program
The facility has established and maintains an emergency response plan that is coordinated with local response agencies.   The plan is designed to protect personnel on the site, to ensure their safe and orderly evacuation in event of an emergency, and to provide notification, appropriate information and protection for response personnel.
